description: VFG049909(gb|WP_001113715) (fha) Type VI secretion system protein Fha [T6SS (VF0579) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Shigella sonnei Ss046]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the Type VI secretion system protein Fha from Shigella sonnei, a critical virulence factor in this enteric bacterial pathogen. This protein functions as a core structural component of the Type VI secretion system (T6SS), a contractile nanomachine that delivers effector proteins directly into target cells. The Fha protein should contain a conserved forkhead-associated (FHA) domain, which mediates phospho-threonine-dependent protein-protein interactions essential for T6SS assembly and function. The protein likely adopts an elongated, multi-domain architecture that facilitates its role in the T6SS baseplate or membrane complex. It should exhibit structural features enabling interaction with other T6SS components such as Hep, VgrG, and Tss proteins, contributing to the assembly of the contractile sheath and spike complex. The sequence must reflect the characteristic features of Gram-negative bacterial secretion system proteins, including appropriate signal sequences for membrane targeting and domains that support the dynamic assembly-disassembly cycle of the T6SS apparatus during effector delivery into host cells.

description: VFG053436(gb|WP_008500810.1) (flgG) flagellar basal-body rod protein FlgG [Flagella (VF1400) - Motility (VFC0204)] [Enterobacter cloacae strain M12X01451]
prompt: Design a protein sequence for the flagellar basal-body rod protein FlgG from Enterobacter cloacae, a clinically significant Gram-negative opportunistic pathogen known for causing hospital-acquired infections, particularly in immunocompromised patients. This protein functions as an essential structural component of the bacterial flagellum, specifically forming part of the basal-body rod that connects the motor complex in the inner membrane to the external hook structure. As a core virulence factor, FlgG enables bacterial motility through flagellar rotation, facilitating chemotaxis, biofilm formation, and host tissue colonization. The protein should contain conserved domains typical of bacterial rod proteins, including helical coiled-coil regions that provide structural rigidity and rod-forming motifs that enable proper assembly and length determination. The sequence should feature transmembrane or membrane-proximal regions for anchoring within the peptidoglycan layer, conserved terminal domains for interaction with other rod proteins (FlgF above and FlgJ below in the assembly hierarchy), and specific recognition sites for the flagellar type III secretion system that coordinates ordered assembly. Structural characteristics should include an elongated, rod-like conformation with periodic repeat domains that stack to form the rigid propeller shaft, conserved hydrophobic patches for protein-protein interactions within the rod complex, and surface-exposed regions that maintain proper diameter and stability while allowing rotational flexibility. The protein must be compatible with the Gram-negative bacterial envelope architecture, traversing the peptidoglycan layer while maintaining connection between the inner membrane motor and the external hook apparatus.

description: VFG006632(gb|WP_000366185) (motA) flagellar motor protein [Flagella (VF0051) - Motility (VFC0204)] [Helicobacter pylori 26695]
prompt: Design a flagellar motor protein from Helicobacter pylori strain 26695, specifically the MotA component, which functions as a critical virulence factor enabling bacterial motility and colonization in the harsh gastric environment. This protein is an integral part of the stator complex of the bacterial flagellar motor, working in conjunction with MotB to generate torque for flagellar rotation. The protein should contain multiple transmembrane helices that anchor it in the inner membrane, forming proton channels that harness the proton motive force to drive motor rotation. Key functional domains should include the conserved ion-conducting motifs responsible for proton translocation and the interaction interfaces with MotB and the rotor components. The structural architecture should facilitate the conversion of proton flow into mechanical rotation, with specific attention to the torque-generating mechanism. This protein plays an essential role in Helicobacter pylori's ability to navigate through gastric mucus, reach the epithelial surface, establish persistent infection, and contribute to gastritis, peptic ulcers, and gastric cancer pathogenesis.

description: VFG013281(gb|WP_005694030) (lpt6) phosphoethanolamine (Petn) transferase [LOS (VF0044) - Immune modulation (VFC0258)] [Haemophilus influenzae Rd KW20]
prompt: Design a functional phosphoethanolamine transferase enzyme from Haemophilus influenzae strain Rd KW20, specifically the Lpt6 protein. This enzyme plays a critical role in bacterial virulence by modifying lipooligosaccharide (LOS) molecules through the addition of phosphoethanolamine groups. As a key immune evasion factor, Lpt6 enables the pathogen to modulate host immune responses by altering LOS surface properties, thereby enhancing bacterial survival and persistence during infection. The enzyme should contain conserved domains characteristic of phosphoethanolamine transferases, including substrate recognition motifs for both LOS acceptor molecules and phosphoethanolamine donor substrates. Structure should feature a catalytic domain with appropriate active site residues for phosphotransfer activity, likely adopting a globular fold with membrane-associated regions for LOS substrate interaction. The protein should demonstrate specificity for LOS modification sites and maintain proper subcellular localization to the bacterial inner membrane or periplasmic space. Include conserved sequence motifs for enzyme activity and substrate binding while ensuring the overall architecture supports efficient transfer of phosphoethanolamine to LOS, contributing to the bacterium's ability to evade host immune detection and establish infection.

description: VFG050860(gb|WP_000301479.1) (gspK) general secretion pathway protein K [T2SS (VF1335) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Acinetobacter baumannii ACICU]
prompt: Generate the amino acid sequence for a Type II Secretion System (T2SS) protein from Acinetobacter baumannii, specifically the general secretion pathway protein K (GspK). This protein is a critical component of the T2SS machinery, which functions as an effector delivery system responsible for transporting virulence factors across the outer membrane in this opportunistic pathogen. GspK is part of the pseudopilus complex, where it likely interacts with other pseudopilin subunits to form a dynamic, pilus-like structure that facilitates the extrusion of folded effector proteins. The protein should contain conserved domains characteristic of type IV pilin-like proteins, including an N-terminal hydrophobic transmembrane helix for membrane anchoring, a conserved glycine-rich motif involved in subunit interactions, and a disulfide-bonded loop structure in the C-terminal domain that contributes to stability and assembly. The sequence should reflect the structural requirements for proper assembly into the pseudopilus, including appropriate hydrophobic regions for membrane association and surface-exposed regions that may interact with other T2SS components or effector proteins. Given Acinetobacter baumannii's role as a multidrug-resistant pathogen associated with hospital-acquired infections, this protein should be optimized for efficient secretion system function while maintaining the structural integrity required for its role in virulence factor transport.

description: VFG048951(gb|WP_015875028) (KP1_RS17330) polysaccharide biosynthesis tyrosine autokinase [Capsule (VF0560) - Immune modulation (VFC0258)] [Klebsiella pneumoniae subsp. pneumoniae NTUH-K2044]
prompt: Generate the amino acid sequence for a polysaccharide biosynthesis tyrosine autokinase from Klebsiella pneumoniae, a Gram-negative opportunistic pathogen notorious for causing severe hospital-acquired infections including pneumonia, bloodstream infections, and urinary tract infections, particularly in immunocompromised patients. This protein functions as a critical virulence factor involved in capsule biosynthesis, where it regulates polysaccharide production through tyrosine autophosphorylation and subsequent phosphotransfer to downstream components. The protein should contain characteristic domains of bacterial tyrosine kinases, including a central catalytic domain with conserved Walker A and Walker B motifs for ATP binding, a C-terminal tyrosine-rich region containing multiple autophosphorylation sites, and potential transmembrane helices or membrane association domains for proper localization to the cytoplasmic membrane. Structurally, it should adopt a bilobed kinase fold with the ATP-binding pocket between the N-terminal and C-terminal lobes, and display the characteristic Hanks-type kinase motifs despite being a bacterial tyrosine kinase. The protein operates within the capsule biosynthesis regulatory network, where its autophosphorylation state controls the activity of response regulators that modulate expression of capsule polysaccharide genes, ultimately determining the thickness and composition of the protective polysaccharide capsule that enables immune evasion, resistance to phagocytosis, and enhanced survival in hostile host environments. The sequence should reflect a modular architecture with distinct functional regions for membrane association, catalytic activity, and regulatory interactions, maintaining the essential residues for tyrosine kinase activity while being optimized for its specific role in coordinating capsule production in this hypervirulent pathogen strain.

description: VFG033536(gb|WP_000622543) (escN) ATPase EscN [TTSS (VF0172) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Escherichia coli O127:H6 str. E2348/69]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the ATPase EscN, a critical component of the Type III Secretion System (T3SS) from the enteropathogenic Escherichia coli O127:H6 strain E2348/69. This protein functions as the primary ATP-hydrolyzing motor that energizes the secretion apparatus, driving the translocation of virulence effector proteins directly into host epithelial cells during bacterial infection. EscN belongs to the conserved family of T3SS ATPases that share homology with the F1/V1-ATPase catalytic subunits, featuring characteristic Walker A and Walker B motifs essential for nucleotide binding and hydrolysis. The protein likely contains additional conserved regions for interaction with the T3SS cytoplasmic C-ring components and the export apparatus, facilitating substrate recognition and unfolding. Structurally, EscN is anticipated to form a hexameric ring complex that couples ATP hydrolysis to the mechanical work of protein translocation through the secretion needle. The sequence should reflect the typical domain architecture of T3SS ATPases, including the catalytic core with conserved residues for Mg²⁺ coordination and ATP binding, while maintaining specificity for the E. coli T3SS context to ensure proper assembly and function within the virulence machinery.

description: VFG048985(gb|WP_014907219) (KP1_RS17355) phosphatase PAP2 family protein [Capsule (VF0560) - Immune modulation (VFC0258)] [Klebsiella pneumoniae subsp. pneumoniae NTUH-K2044]
prompt: Design a functional phosphatase enzyme from Klebsiella pneumoniae, a significant human pathogen known for causing hospital-acquired infections including pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and bacteremia, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. This protein belongs to the PAP2 (phosphatidic acid phosphatase type 2) family and functions as a virulence factor involved in capsule biosynthesis and immune modulation. The enzyme should contain characteristic PAP2 family domains with conserved active site motifs, likely featuring multiple transmembrane helices typical of membrane-associated phosphatases. It should exhibit specificity for lipid phosphate substrates, potentially participating in the modification of capsule polysaccharides or membrane components to evade host immune recognition. The protein's mechanism involves dephosphorylation reactions that alter bacterial surface properties, contributing to immune evasion by interfering with complement activation or phagocytosis. Structural features should include the conserved phosphatase catalytic domain with essential histidine and aspartate residues in the active site, arranged in a membrane-integrated conformation that facilitates interaction with lipid substrates. The protein functions within the capsule biosynthesis pathway, modifying intermediates to produce the complete capsular polysaccharide that protects the bacterium from host defenses.

description: VFG002447(gb|WP_004188590) (bipD) Type III secretion system needle tip protein BipD [Bsa T3SS (VF0428) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Burkholderia pseudomallei K96243]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the Type III secretion system needle tip protein BipD from Burkholderia pseudomallei. This protein serves as a critical virulence factor in the Bsa Type III secretion system, functioning as the needle tip complex component that forms the translocon pore at the apex of the secretion apparatus. BipD is essential for effector protein translocation into host cells during bacterial infection, acting as the initial contact point with host membranes. The protein should contain conserved domains characteristic of T3SS needle tip proteins, including a central beta-sandwich fold domain that mediates oligomerization with other translocon components BipB and BipC. Key structural features should include surface-exposed loops involved in host membrane interaction, hydrophobic regions for membrane insertion, and conserved residues critical for pore formation and effector protein passage. The sequence should reflect the protein's localization at the bacterial surface as part of the injectisome complex, with appropriate signal sequences for secretion through the T3SS apparatus. Burkholderia pseudomallei is a highly virulent intracellular pathogen causing melioidosis, and the Bsa T3SS is essential for its ability to escape phagosomes, replicate intracellularly, and induce actin-based motility. The generated sequence must maintain the structural integrity required for forming a functional translocon pore while preserving the specific molecular recognition features that enable selective effector protein passage during host cell invasion.

description: VFG043349(gb|WP_010947508) (LPG_RS08925) RNA polymerase sigma factor FliA [Flagella (VF0157) - Motility (VFC0204)] [Legionella pneumophila subsp. pneumophila str. Philadelphia 1]
prompt: Design a functional RNA polymerase sigma factor FliA protein from Legionella pneumophila, the causative agent of Legionnaires' disease. This sigma factor is specifically dedicated to the transcription of flagellar genes, enabling bacterial motility which is essential for virulence, host colonization, and environmental persistence. The protein should function as an alternative sigma factor that recognizes and binds to flagellar class 3 promoter sequences, directing RNA polymerase to initiate transcription of late-stage flagellar genes including those encoding flagellin, hook-associated proteins, and motor components. The sequence should contain conserved sigma factor domains: region 2.4 for -10 promoter element recognition with specificity for flagellar promoters, region 4.2 for -35 element recognition, and the characteristic sigma factor structural fold that enables interaction with the RNA polymerase core enzyme. The protein should exhibit appropriate subcellular localization to the cytoplasm where it can access the transcription machinery and should maintain the regulatory features that ensure its expression is coupled to the hierarchical flagellar assembly pathway, being transcribed only after earlier flagellar genes are properly expressed and assembled.

description: VFG000977(gb|WP_002985285) (sagA) streptolysin S associated protein [SLS (VF0251) - Exotoxin (VFC0235)] [Streptococcus pyogenes M1 GAS]
prompt: Generate the amino acid sequence for SagA, a critical virulence factor from Streptococcus pyogenes serotype M1. This protein is an essential component of the streptolysin S (SLS) toxin complex, a potent exotoxin responsible for the characteristic beta-hemolytic phenotype of Group A Streptococcus. SagA functions as the structural scaffold and carrier protein for the post-translationally modified SLS peptide toxin. The protein likely contains conserved domains for binding and stabilizing the modified peptide toxin, including potential amphipathic regions that facilitate membrane interaction and pore formation. Structurally, SagA should possess regions that coordinate with other Sag proteins (SagB-SagI) in the SLS biosynthesis operon, forming a multi-component complex that synthesizes, modifies, and exports the mature toxin. The protein should exhibit characteristics typical of bacterial toxin-associated carrier proteins, including appropriate hydrophobicity patterns for membrane association and specific binding motifs for the modified cytolysin peptide. The sequence must reflect the protein's role in facilitating the assembly of the oxygen-stable, non-immunogenic SLS toxin that lyses erythrocytes, leukocytes, and platelets, contributing significantly to S. pyogenes pathogenesis in invasive infections such as necrotizing fasciitis and streptococcal toxic shock syndrome.

description: VFG000535(gb|NP_461794) (prgI) type III secretion system needle filament protein PrgI [TTSS (SPI-1 encode) (VF0116) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium str. LT2]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for PrgI, the type III secretion system needle filament protein from Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium. This protein is a critical structural component of the T3SS injectisome apparatus, forming the hollow needle structure that spans from the bacterial envelope to the host cell membrane. PrgI should contain conserved domains characteristic of T3SS needle proteins, including a central coiled-coil region that facilitates protein-protein interactions and oligomerization into the needle polymer. The protein must feature an N-terminal secretion signal for T3SS-mediated export, hydrophobic regions for membrane association, and surface-exposed residues that may interact with host cell receptors during the translocation process. The sequence should reflect the protein's role in bridging the bacterial and host cell interfaces, enabling the direct injection of virulence effector proteins into eukaryotic cells during Salmonella invasion. Key functional motifs should include residues involved in needle length control, stability maintenance, and potential regulatory interactions with other T3SS components like the inner membrane ring and tip complex proteins.

description: VFG047889(gb|WP_003018233) (iglG) PAAR-like T6SS protein [T6SS (VF0544) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Francisella tularensis subsp. tularensis SCHU S4]

This protein functions as a critical virulence factor in the T6SS effector delivery system, which is essential for bacterial pathogenesis and intracellular survival. The protein should contain the characteristic PAAR domain that forms the sharp tip of the T6SS spike complex, facilitating effector protein translocation into host cells. The structural architecture should support its role in piercing host cell membranes and delivering toxic effector proteins that enable bacterial evasion of host immune responses and establishment of intracellular niches.

description: VFG002014(gb|WP_010947513) (fliR) flagellar biosynthetic protein FliR [Flagella (VF0157) - Motility (VFC0204)] [Legionella pneumophila subsp. pneumophila str. Philadelphia 1]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the flagellar biosynthetic protein FliR from Legionella pneumophila, a critical component of the bacterial flagellar type III secretion system (T3SS). This protein functions as an integral membrane component of the flagellar export apparatus, specifically forming part of the transmembrane export gate complex that facilitates the selective translocation of flagellar structural subunits from the cytoplasm to the growing flagellar structure. The protein should contain conserved domains characteristic of FliR family proteins, including multiple transmembrane helices that anchor it within the inner membrane, forming a central channel for substrate passage. The sequence should reflect its role in recognizing and transporting flagellar proteins such as flagellin, hook protein, and rod components through ATPase-independent mechanisms. Structural features should include hydrophobic regions for membrane integration, conserved residues involved in protein-protein interactions with other export apparatus components (FliP, FliQ, FlhA, FlhB), and potential recognition motifs for substrate binding. The protein plays an essential role in Legionella pneumophila virulence by enabling flagellum-mediated motility, which is crucial for host cell invasion, tissue colonization, and evasion of host immune responses in Legionnaires' disease pathogenesis.

description: VFG001986(gb|YP_002344796) (kpsS) capsule polysaccharide modification protein [Capsule (VF0323) - Immune modulation (VFC0258)] [Campylobacter jejuni subsp. jejuni NCTC 11168]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the KpsS protein from Campylobacter jejuni subsp. jejuni NCTC 11168, a critical virulence factor involved in capsule polysaccharide modification. This protein functions as a key component in the biosynthesis and export of the capsular polysaccharide, which is essential for immune evasion, serum resistance, and host colonization. KpsS is part of the capsule transport system that facilitates the translocation of polysaccharide precursors across the cytoplasmic membrane. The protein likely contains conserved domains characteristic of polysaccharide modification enzymes, potentially including glycosyltransferase motifs, nucleotide-sugar binding sites, and membrane-associated regions for interaction with the transport machinery. The structure should reflect a soluble cytoplasmic protein with specific catalytic residues for sugar modification and conserved regions for protein-protein interactions within the capsule biosynthesis complex. The sequence must maintain functional integrity for proper polysaccharide processing, ensuring the capsule's structural diversity and antigenic variation that enables Campylobacter jejuni to evade host immune responses and establish infection.

description: VFG000194(gb|NP_250390) (pcr1) type III secretion system protein Pcr1 [TTSS (VF0083) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Pseudomonas aeruginosa PAO1]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the Pcr1 protein, a critical component of the Type III Secretion System (T3SS) in Pseudomonas aeruginosa. This opportunistic pathogen employs its T3SS as a molecular syringe to inject effector proteins directly into host cells, subverting immune responses and promoting infection. Pcr1 functions as a structural and regulatory element within the T3SS needle complex, specifically contributing to the assembly and stability of the secretion apparatus. The protein likely contains conserved domains characteristic of T3SS components, such as coiled-coil regions that facilitate protein-protein interactions within the multi-subunit complex, and may possess transmembrane segments or amphipathic helices for membrane association. Its mechanism involves coordinating with other T3SS proteins to form the conduit through which virulence effectors are translocated into eukaryotic cells. The sequence should reflect a globular protein with both soluble and membrane-proximal regions, maintaining key residues for oligomerization and interaction with partner proteins like PcrV and PopB/PopD, ensuring proper needle complex formation and effector delivery. Structural features should include alpha-helical bundles and beta-strands that confer stability under host environmental stresses, with conserved motifs essential for its role in this sophisticated bacterial weapon system.

description: VFG000669(gb|NP_706257) (gtrA) bactoprenol-linked glucose translocase/flippase [LPS (VF0124) - Immune modulation (VFC0258)] [Shigella flexneri 2a str. 301]

The protein should contain characteristic transmembrane domains that facilitate its integration into the inner membrane, where it acts as a flippase to translocate bactoprenol-linked glucose precursors from the cytoplasmic to the periplasmic face. Key functional motifs should include residues involved in substrate binding and flipping, such as those coordinating the bactoprenol phosphate carrier and glucose moiety. The protein likely adopts a multi-pass transmembrane structure with conserved domains typical of flippase enzymes, enabling its role in the LPS biosynthesis pathway and contributing to the serotype variation and pathogenicity of Shigella flexneri.

description: VFG039141(gb|NP_820611) (icmL.1/dotI) Type IVB secretion system protein IcmL [Dot/Icm T4SS (VF0503) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Coxiella burnetii RSA 493]

This protein functions as an essential structural and regulatory element within the bacterial virulence apparatus responsible for intracellular survival and pathogenesis. IcmL should contain conserved domains characteristic of Type IV secretion system proteins, including transmembrane helices for membrane integration and regions mediating protein-protein interactions with other Dot/Icm components. The protein likely adopts a multi-domain architecture with both periplasmic and cytoplasmic regions, facilitating its role in substrate recognition, complex assembly, and effector protein translocation. Structural features should include alpha-helical bundles and beta-sheet regions that contribute to stability within the secretion apparatus. The sequence must maintain key functional motifs for ATP binding/hydrolysis if applicable, and conserved residues critical for interactions with partner proteins like DotK and other core complex components. The generated protein should reflect the evolutionary optimization for intracellular parasitism, with appropriate hydrophobicity profiles for membrane association and surface characteristics compatible with host cell membrane interactions during the establishment of the Coxiella-containing vacuole.

description: VFG038371(gb|WP_011705707) (vgrG2) VgrG protein [T6SS (VF0480) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Aeromonas hydrophila subsp. hydrophila ATCC 7966]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the VgrG2 protein from Aeromonas hydrophila subsp. hydrophila ATCC 7966, a critical component of the Type VI Secretion System (T6SS) effector delivery machinery. This protein functions as a structural and functional component of the T6SS nanomachine, serving as both a puncturing device and a carrier for effector proteins. The VgrG2 protein should contain conserved domains characteristic of the VgrG family, including an N-terminal domain that integrates with the T6SS baseplate complex, a central trimeric coiled-coil region that forms the rigid spike structure, and a C-terminal domain that may serve as an effector domain or facilitate effector protein loading. The protein should exhibit structural features enabling it to penetrate target cell membranes during T6SS firing, with specific motifs for interaction with other T6SS components such as Hcp and the membrane complex. The sequence should reflect the protein's role in bacterial virulence, including features that enable it to withstand the mechanical forces during membrane penetration and maintain structural integrity within the T6SS apparatus. Consider the protein's subcellular localization to the bacterial envelope and its assembly into the T6SS contractile sheath structure. The generated sequence must be functionally competent for its dual role as both a structural component of the secretion apparatus and a delivery vehicle for virulence effectors.

description: VFG013265(gb|WP_005694045) (orfM) deoxyribonucleotide triphosphate pyrophosphatase [LOS (VF0044) - Immune modulation (VFC0258)] [Haemophilus influenzae Rd KW20]
prompt: Design a deoxyribonucleotide triphosphate pyrophosphatase protein from Haemophilus influenzae strain Rd KW20, specifically the orfM gene product. This enzyme functions as a key virulence factor by modulating host immune responses through the degradation of deoxyribonucleotide triphosphates, thereby interfering with DNA synthesis and repair processes in host cells. The protein should contain conserved pyrophosphatase domains characteristic of the dUTPase superfamily, featuring the characteristic five-stranded β-barrel structure with α-helices packing against the barrel. Key functional motifs should include the conserved active site residues responsible for metal ion coordination and substrate binding, particularly for dUTP and other deoxyribonucleotide triphosphates. The enzyme likely functions as a trimer in its active form, with each monomer contributing to the complete catalytic site. Structural features should include the characteristic P-loop motif for nucleotide binding and conserved acidic residues for magnesium ion coordination. The protein should be localized to the bacterial cytoplasm where it regulates nucleotide pools, but its activity indirectly affects host-pathogen interactions by limiting nucleotide availability for host immune cell proliferation and DNA repair mechanisms. The enzyme's specificity for deoxyribonucleotides over ribonucleotides should be reflected in the substrate binding pocket architecture, with conserved aromatic residues for base stacking interactions and polar residues for ribose discrimination.

description: VFG000193(gb|NP_250389) (popN) type III secretion system outer membrane protein PopN [TTSS (VF0083) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Pseudomonas aeruginosa PAO1]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the PopN protein, a critical component of the Type III Secretion System (T3SS) in Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a Gram-negative opportunistic pathogen notorious for causing severe infections in immunocompromised individuals, cystic fibrosis patients, and those with hospital-acquired pneumonia. As an outer membrane protein of the T3SS apparatus, PopN functions as a structural and regulatory element within the needle complex, which is essential for the translocation of effector proteins directly into host cells. The protein likely contains multiple transmembrane beta-barrel domains characteristic of outer membrane proteins, facilitating its integration into the bacterial outer membrane. PopN is expected to participate in the assembly and stabilization of the T3SS translocon, potentially interacting with other T3SS components such as PcrG or PcrH to regulate effector secretion. The sequence should reflect conserved regions involved in protein-protein interactions, membrane anchoring, and possibly a periplasmic domain for coordinating with inner membrane components. Structurally, anticipate a globular domain exposed extracellularly or periplasmically, with hydrophobic stretches for membrane insertion. The overall architecture must support its role in maintaining the integrity of the secretion channel and ensuring efficient delivery of virulence factors like ExoS or ExoU, which disrupt host cell signaling and promote bacterial survival.

description: VFG047834(gb|WP_003016192) (vgrG) Type VI secretion system secreted protein VgrG [T6SS (VF0544) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Francisella tularensis subsp. tularensis SCHU S4]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the VgrG protein from Francisella tularensis subsp. tularensis, a highly virulent bacterial pathogen and the causative agent of tularemia. This protein functions as a core structural component and effector delivery device within the Type VI Secretion System (T6SS), a contractile nanomachine essential for bacterial pathogenesis. The VgrG protein serves as the puncturing tip of the T6SS apparatus, featuring a conserved trimeric structure with a central beta-helical spike domain that facilitates membrane penetration of target eukaryotic cells. It contains characteristic domains including an N-terminal T6SS baseplate-binding domain for complex assembly, a central coiled-coil region that forms the rigid spike structure, and a C-terminal effector domain that may function as a specialized toxin or carry additional effector proteins. The protein must maintain structural integrity for proper assembly into the T6SS contractile sheath while possessing the mechanical properties necessary for membrane disruption. Key functional motifs should include conserved residues for trimerization stability, regions for interaction with other T6SS components such as Hcp and PAAR proteins, and potential glycoside hydrolase or peptidoglycan-degrading activities in the C-terminal domain that contribute to host cell wall penetration. The sequence should reflect the characteristic modular architecture that allows VgrG to serve both structural and effector functions simultaneously, with appropriate signal sequences for T6SS-mediated secretion and domains optimized for interaction with the bacterial inner membrane complex during assembly.

description: VFG002013(gb|WP_011946726) (flhB) flagellar biosynthetic protein FlhB [Flagella (VF0157) - Motility (VFC0204)] [Legionella pneumophila subsp. pneumophila str. Philadelphia 1]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the flagellar biosynthetic protein FlhB from Legionella pneumophila, a critical component of the flagellar type III secretion system (T3SS) essential for bacterial motility and virulence. This transmembrane protein functions as a molecular switch that regulates substrate specificity during flagellar assembly, transitioning from early rod/hook components to late filament subunits. The protein should contain conserved domains including an N-terminal transmembrane region with four predicted membrane-spanning helices that anchor it to the inner membrane, and a large C-terminal cytoplasmic domain featuring the conserved FHIPEP motif that interacts with the FlhA protein to form the export apparatus. The cytoplasmic domain should include the autocatalytic cleavage site between residues N269 and P270, where self-cleavage activates the substrate specificity switch. Key functional motifs should include the gate loop region that controls substrate access and the recognition sites for chaperone-substrate complexes. The protein must maintain structural compatibility with other flagellar T3SS components including FlhA, FliO, FliP, FliQ, and FliR to form the functional export gate complex. The sequence should reflect adaptation to Legionella's aquatic environment and intracellular lifestyle, with appropriate hydrophobicity profiles for membrane integration and cytoplasmic domain folding that supports its role in coordinating the hierarchical assembly of the flagellar apparatus, which is crucial for Legionella's ability to colonize water systems and initiate human respiratory infections.

description: VFG053422(gb|WP_013097134.1) (flgI) flagellar basal body P-ring protein FlgI [Flagella (VF1400) - Motility (VFC0204)] [Enterobacter cloacae strain M12X01451]
prompt: Generate the amino acid sequence for the flagellar basal body P-ring protein FlgI from Enterobacter cloacae, a key structural component of the bacterial flagellar motor apparatus. This protein functions as an essential virulence factor by enabling bacterial motility through the assembly of the P-ring, which forms part of the basal body structure that anchors the flagellum to the cell envelope. The P-ring specifically spans the peptidoglycan layer, providing structural stability and serving as a bushing for the rotating flagellar rod. The protein should contain conserved domains characteristic of P-ring proteins, including regions for proper insertion into the peptidoglycan matrix and interaction with other basal body components such as the L-ring and rod proteins. The sequence should reflect a typical gram-negative bacterial P-ring protein architecture with appropriate signal peptides for outer membrane localization, conserved hydrophobic regions for membrane association, and structural motifs that facilitate the formation of a stable ring structure around the flagellar rod. The protein must maintain the mechanical properties necessary to withstand the torque generated during flagellar rotation while allowing smooth rotation of the central rod.

description: VFG042568(gb|WP_000012016) (sfaY) transcriptional regulator SfaY [F1C fimbriae (VF0224) - Adherence (VFC0001)] [Escherichia coli CFT073]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the transcriptional regulator SfaY from uropathogenic Escherichia coli strain CFT073. This protein functions as a key virulence factor by regulating the expression of F1C fimbriae, which are critical adhesive structures that mediate bacterial attachment to host epithelial cells in the urinary tract. SfaY belongs to the AraC/XylS family of transcriptional regulators and likely contains a conserved DNA-binding domain with helix-turn-helix motifs that recognize specific promoter sequences upstream of fimbrial operon genes. This protein functions as a critical component of the bacterial flagellum, specifically within the C-ring structure at the base of the flagellar motor. As a virulence factor, FliN enables bacterial motility and chemotaxis, essential for host colonization and pathogenesis. The protein should contain conserved domains characteristic of flagellar switch proteins, including the FliN domain responsible for torque generation and directional control. It should form part of a multi-subunit complex with FliG and FliM, facilitating the switch between clockwise and counterclockwise rotation in response to chemotactic signals. The structure should feature appropriate binding interfaces for interaction with other C-ring components and the motor stator proteins. Include conserved motifs for CheY-P binding and signal transduction, ensuring the protein can undergo conformational changes that reverse motor rotation direction. The sequence should reflect the thermostability requirements of a human pathogen and maintain the amphipathic character necessary for membrane-proximal localization within the flagellar basal body.

description: VFG002016(gb|WP_010947515) (fliP) flagellar biosynthetic protein FliP [Flagella (VF0157) - Motility (VFC0204)] [Legionella pneumophila subsp. pneumophila str. Philadelphia 1]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the flagellar biosynthetic protein FliP from Legionella pneumophila, a critical component in the assembly of the bacterial flagellum, which is essential for motility, chemotaxis, and virulence in this opportunistic human pathogen. FliP functions as part of the flagellar type III secretion system (fT3SS) export apparatus, specifically forming a transmembrane ring complex within the inner membrane that facilitates the selective translocation of flagellar structural subunits (e.g., rod, hook, and filament proteins) from the cytoplasm to the growing flagellar structure. The protein must contain multiple transmembrane helices to anchor it in the inner membrane, conserved domains typical of FliP family proteins (e.g., involved in substrate recognition and export), and key residues for interactions with other export apparatus components like FliQ and FliR. Its mechanism involves ATP-independent protein export driven by the proton motive force, contributing directly to Legionella's ability to navigate aqueous environments, infect alveolar macrophages, and cause Legionnaires' disease. Ensure the sequence reflects a bacterial protein with no eukaryotic motifs, appropriate hydrophobicity for membrane integration, and functional regions supporting its role in the stepwise assembly of the flagellar basal body and axial components.

description: VFG038378(gb|WP_011705712) (vipA) Type VI secretion system contractile sheath small subunit TssB/VipA [T6SS (VF0480) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Aeromonas hydrophila subsp. hydrophila ATCC 7966]
prompt: Design a protein sequence for the VipA protein, a core structural component of the Type VI Secretion System (T6SS) from Aeromonas hydrophila. This organism is a significant aquatic pathogen causing septicemia and wound infections in fish and humans. VipA functions as the small subunit of the contractile sheath that forms the central apparatus of the T6SS, a molecular syringe that delivers effector proteins directly into target cells. The protein should contain conserved domains characteristic of TssB/VipA family members, including helical regions that facilitate polymerization into a tubular sheath structure around the inner tube component. This sheath undergoes ATP-dependent contraction to propel the inner tube and associated effectors through the target cell membrane. The sequence should reflect structural features enabling proper oligomerization with the large sheath subunit VipB/TssC, maintaining the extended sheath conformation in the pre-firing state and facilitating rapid contraction upon activation. Key functional motifs should support interactions with the baseplate complex for sheath assembly and with the ClpV ATPase for sheath disassembly and recycling. The protein should localize to the bacterial cytoplasm and inner membrane interface, forming the dynamic contractile machinery essential for T6SS-mediated virulence.

description: VFG000037(gb|WP_003807114) (bplB) probable acetyltransferase [LPS (VF0033) - Immune modulation (VFC0258)] [Bordetella pertussis Tohama I]
prompt: Design a protein sequence for a bacterial acetyltransferase that functions as a key virulence factor in Bordetella pertussis, the causative agent of whooping cough. This protein, designated bplB, plays a critical role in immune modulation through lipopolysaccharide (LPS) modification. The enzyme should catalyze the transfer of acetyl groups to specific positions on the LPS core or lipid A moiety, thereby altering the host immune recognition and reducing Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4)-mediated inflammatory responses. The protein should contain conserved acetyltransferase domains, including characteristic motifs for acetyl-CoA binding and catalytic residues essential for acetyl group transfer. It should exhibit structural features typical of bacterial acetyltransferases, with a well-defined active site pocket capable of accommodating both the acetyl-CoA donor and LPS acceptor substrates. The protein should be localized to the bacterial inner membrane or periplasmic space to facilitate access to the LPS biosynthesis pathway. Include appropriate signal sequences or membrane association domains if required for proper localization and function. The overall structure should maintain stability in the bacterial envelope environment while enabling efficient interaction with LPS substrates and cofactors.

description: VFG000225(gb|WP_002221781) (pilS) pilin [Type IV pili (VF0075) - Adherence (VFC0001)] [Neisseria meningitidis MC58]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the PilS protein from Neisseria meningitidis strain MC58, a key transcriptional regulator in the type IV pilus biogenesis system. This protein functions as a response regulator within a two-component signal transduction system, specifically responding to environmental cues to control the expression of pilin and other pilus-associated genes. PilS is part of the PilS/PilR regulatory pair, where it acts as the sensor histidine kinase that autophosphorylates upon detecting specific signals, then transfers the phosphate group to its cognate response regulator PilR, which subsequently activates transcription of pilus operons. The protein should contain characteristic domains of bacterial sensor kinases: an N-terminal transmembrane domain for signal perception and localization to the inner membrane, a central HAMP domain for signal transduction, and a C-terminal histidine kinase domain featuring the conserved H-box, N-box, G-box, and F-box motifs essential for ATP binding and autophosphorylation at the conserved histidine residue. The structural organization should facilitate dimerization through the histidine kinase domain, with the periplasmic sensor domain likely containing recognition sites for environmental stimuli that modulate pilus expression in response to host contact or other virulence-associated conditions. The generated sequence must reflect the functional requirements for proper membrane integration, signal transduction, and phosphorylation activity that enables Neisseria meningitidis to dynamically regulate type IV pilus expression during colonization and invasion of human mucosal surfaces.

description: VFG000387(gb|WP_002229794) (sycN) chaperone for YopN [TTSS (VF0140) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Yersinia pestis CO92]
prompt: Design a functional chaperone protein for the Yersinia pestis Type III Secretion System (TTSS). This protein, SycN, is essential for the virulence of Yersinia pestis, the causative agent of plague, by specifically binding to and stabilizing the YopN effector protein. SycN functions as a specialized chaperone that prevents premature aggregation and degradation of YopN in the bacterial cytoplasm, facilitates its efficient translocation through the TTSS needle complex, and ensures proper targeting to host cells. The protein should contain characteristic chaperone domains with hydrophobic binding pockets for YopN interaction, conserved alpha-helical regions for structural stability, and specific recognition motifs for TTSS apparatus engagement. It must maintain optimal stability for intracellular function while exhibiting high specificity for YopN binding without interfering with other TTSS components. The structural architecture should support transient complex formation with YopN and efficient release at the translocation interface.

description: VFG038882(gb|WP_005314247) (maf-5) modification accessory factor [Lateral flagella (VF0474) - Motility (VFC0204)] [Aeromonas salmonicida subsp. salmonicida A449]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for Maf-5, a modification accessory factor from Aeromonas salmonicida subsp. salmonicida. This protein functions as a critical virulence factor within the lateral flagella system, specifically contributing to the motility apparatus that enables bacterial movement through viscous environments and host tissue colonization. As a modification accessory factor, Maf-5 likely facilitates post-translational modifications of flagellar structural components, potentially through glycosylation, methylation, or other enzymatic activities that ensure proper flagellar assembly and function. The protein should contain conserved domains characteristic of bacterial modification enzymes, possibly including nucleotide-binding motifs for cofactor interaction and catalytic residues for transferase activity. Structurally, anticipate a compact globular fold with active site pockets for substrate recognition and modification. Maf-5 operates within the lateral flagella biosynthesis pathway, interacting with flagellar hook-basal body components and modification substrates to enable the production of functional, rotating flagella that propel the bacterium. The sequence should reflect the thermophilic adaptation of Aeromonas salmonicida, with appropriate amino acid composition for stability and function in the fish pathogen's environmental niche.

description: VFG000383(gb|WP_002220918) (lcrR) low calcium response protein R [TTSS (VF0140) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Yersinia pestis CO92]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the LcrR protein from Yersinia pestis strain CO92, a key transcriptional regulator within the Type III Secretion System (T3SS) virulence apparatus. This protein functions as a critical component of the low calcium response regulatory cascade, where it modulates the expression of T3SS structural components and effector proteins in response to extracellular calcium concentrations encountered during host infection. LcrR operates as part of a sophisticated regulatory complex, likely interacting with other regulators like LcrG and LcrV to control the hierarchical expression of the Yersinia virulence plasmid-encoded genes. The protein should contain conserved DNA-binding domains characteristic of transcriptional regulators, potentially including helix-turn-helix motifs for specific promoter recognition. It should feature calcium-responsive regulatory domains that undergo conformational changes upon calcium binding, enabling the switch between repressive and permissive transcriptional states. The sequence must include appropriate signal integration regions that sense environmental cues and transduce this information to the DNA-binding apparatus. Structural elements should facilitate protein-protein interactions within the regulatory complex while maintaining the precise allosteric control necessary for coordinated virulence gene expression. The generated sequence must reflect the functional requirements for rapid response to host environmental signals and precise transcriptional control essential for Yersinia pestis pathogenesis.

description: VFG006986(gb|WP_000828585) (mshA) MSHA pilin protein MshA [MSHA pili (VF0515) - Adherence (VFC0001)] [Vibrio cholerae O1 biovar El Tor str. N16961]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the MSHA pilin protein MshA from Vibrio cholerae O1 biovar El Tor strain N16961. This protein serves as the major structural subunit of the mannose-sensitive hemagglutinin (MSHA) type IV pili, which are critical virulence factors for bacterial adherence and colonization in the human host. The MSHA pili mediate attachment to intestinal epithelial cells through specific recognition of mannose-containing receptors on host cell surfaces, facilitating the initial stages of cholera infection. The MshA protein should contain conserved domains and motifs characteristic of type IV pilins, including an N-terminal hydrophobic transmembrane helix that anchors the protein in the inner membrane prior to assembly, a conserved disulfide-bonded region in the C-terminal domain that stabilizes the pilus structure, and specific receptor-binding residues that confer mannose sensitivity. The protein must be capable of polymerization into helical pilus filaments through hydrophobic interactions between N-terminal domains, while exposing the C-terminal receptor-binding domain on the pilus surface. The sequence should reflect the structural requirements for pilus assembly machinery recognition and should maintain the amphipathic character necessary for both membrane integration and extracellular filament formation. The generated protein must be functional for host cell adhesion while evading immediate immune recognition, supporting Vibrio cholerae's pathogenesis in the human gastrointestinal tract.

description: VFG045463(gb|WP_080502933) (APH_RS05735*) P44/Msp2 family outer membrane protein [P44/Msp2 family (VF0520) - Immune modulation (VFC0258)] [Anaplasma phagocytophilum HZ]
prompt: Design a complete protein sequence for the P44/Msp2 family outer membrane protein from Anaplasma phagocytophilum, an obligate intracellular bacterium that causes human granulocytic anaplasmosis. This protein functions as a major surface antigen and virulence factor that enables immune evasion through antigenic variation. The protein should be localized to the bacterial outer membrane and function as an adhesin that facilitates host cell attachment and invasion. Incorporate the characteristic P44/Msp2 family domain architecture, including conserved transmembrane beta-barrel structures typical of bacterial outer membrane proteins, with surface-exposed hypervariable regions that undergo recombination to generate antigenic diversity. Include functional motifs for membrane insertion and surface exposure that allow the bacterium to periodically alter its surface antigen profile, thereby evading host immune recognition and establishing persistent infection. The protein should demonstrate structural features compatible with outer membrane localization while maintaining the capacity for rapid sequence variation in surface-exposed loops to subvert adaptive immune responses.

description: VFG000040(gb|WP_010930814) (bscW) Bordetella Bsc type III secretion system protein BscW [TTSS (VF0035) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Bordetella pertussis Tohama I]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for BscW, a critical component of the Bordetella type III secretion system (T3SS) from Bordetella pertussis. As a key virulence factor in whooping cough pathogenesis, BscW functions as an essential translocator protein within the Bsc T3SS apparatus. This protein is responsible for forming the translocation pore in host cell membranes, facilitating the delivery of bacterial effector proteins into target eukaryotic cells. The sequence should contain characteristic domains of T3SS translocators, including hydrophobic regions for membrane insertion and domains involved in pore formation and host membrane interaction. BscW likely exhibits structural features typical of translocator proteins, with regions that undergo conformational changes upon contact with host membranes. The protein operates in concert with other T3SS components, particularly working alongside the needle complex to bridge the bacterial and host cell interfaces. Include conserved motifs essential for its interaction with chaperone proteins and other T3SS machinery components. The sequence should reflect the protein's role in establishing the translocation conduit that enables Bordetella pertussis to subvert host immune responses and establish respiratory tract colonization.

description: VFG000386(gb|WP_002212969) (yscX) type III secretion system protein YscX [TTSS (VF0140) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Yersinia pestis CO92]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the YscX protein, a critical component of the Type III Secretion System (T3SS) from Yersinia pestis, the causative agent of plague. This protein functions as an essential chaperone within the T3SS injectisome complex, specifically facilitating the stabilization and proper delivery of effector proteins into host cells during bacterial pathogenesis. YscX should contain conserved domains characteristic of T3SS chaperones, including substrate-binding regions that interact with specific effector proteins and regulatory domains that coordinate with other T3SS components. The protein likely adopts a compact, globular fold with exposed hydrophobic patches for effector binding and flexible regions that allow dynamic interactions within the secretion apparatus. Structurally, it should maintain key alpha-helical and beta-sheet elements typical of secretion chaperones, with conserved surface residues mediating protein-protein interactions with both effector proteins and other T3SS components like the needle complex. The sequence must encode appropriate subcellular localization signals to ensure proper positioning within the bacterial membrane-associated T3SS machinery, and include functional motifs that regulate effector recognition, prevent premature degradation, and coordinate the hierarchical secretion process. The generated protein should exhibit the characteristic biochemical properties of a T3SS chaperone, including appropriate molecular weight, pI, and stability parameters suitable for its role in this sophisticated bacterial weapon system.

description: VFG049905(gb|WP_000343289) (tssL) Type VI secretion system protein TssL [T6SS (VF0579) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Shigella sonnei Ss046]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the Type VI secretion system protein TssL from Shigella sonnei, a Gram-negative bacterial pathogen responsible for bacillary dysentery. This protein functions as a critical structural component of the Type VI secretion system (T6SS), a contractile nanomachine that delivers effector proteins directly into target cells. TssL serves as an essential membrane-anchored subunit of the T6SS baseplate complex, forming part of the trans-envelope assembly that spans both the inner and outer membranes. The protein should contain a single transmembrane domain near its N-terminus for proper membrane integration, followed by a large cytoplasmic domain that interacts with other T6SS components including TssM, TssK, and the TssJ outer membrane lipoprotein. The cytoplasmic region should feature conserved helical bundles and protein-protein interaction interfaces essential for baseplate assembly and stability. The sequence must maintain key conserved residues for oligomerization and for forming the interface with the TssM protein, which together create the membrane-spanning complex. The overall structure should facilitate the proper assembly of the contractile sheath and spike apparatus, enabling the injection of toxic effectors into eukaryotic host cells during Shigella pathogenesis. The generated sequence should reflect the characteristic features of bacterial T6SS membrane components while maintaining functional specificity for Shigella virulence.

description: VFG043360(gb|WP_010948024) (motA) flagellar motor stator protein MotA [Flagella (VF0157) - Motility (VFC0204)] [Legionella pneumophila subsp. pneumophila str. Philadelphia 1]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the flagellar motor stator protein MotA from Legionella pneumophila, a critical virulence factor enabling this opportunistic pathogen's motility and host colonization. This transmembrane protein functions as the essential proton channel that energizes flagellar rotation by converting proton motive force into mechanical torque. Design the protein with four transmembrane helices forming the proton conduction pathway, with key conserved residues for proton translocation including essential aspartate and arginine residues in the cytoplasmic loop regions. Include the characteristic cytoplasmic domains that interact with the MotB partner protein to form the stable stator complex anchored to the peptidoglycan layer. The protein must maintain the proper topology with N- and C-terminal regions facing the cytoplasm, and incorporate the conserved motifs required for torque generation and regulation of stator assembly around the flagellar basal body. Ensure the sequence reflects adaptation to Legionella's aquatic and intracellular lifestyle, with appropriate hydrophobicity patterns for membrane integration and cytoplasmic domains optimized for protein-protein interactions within the flagellar motor complex.

description: VFG000032(gb|WP_010929610) (bplG) probable sugar transferase [LPS (VF0033) - Immune modulation (VFC0258)] [Bordetella pertussis Tohama I]
prompt: Design a functionally correct protein sequence for a sugar transferase virulence factor from Bordetella pertussis, the causative agent of whooping cough. This enzyme plays a critical role in lipopolysaccharide (LPS) biosynthesis, specifically in the modification of the core oligosaccharide or O-antigen component. As a key virulence determinant, it contributes to immune modulation by altering the surface properties of the bacterial outer membrane, thereby enhancing resistance to host complement-mediated killing and modulating Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4) signaling. The protein should contain conserved glycosyltransferase domains, likely adopting a GT-B fold architecture characterized by two distinct Rossmann-fold domains separated by a deep catalytic cleft. Key structural motifs should include a nucleotide-sugar binding pocket with conserved DXD or related motifs for coordinating divalent cations (typically Mn²⁺ or Mg²⁺), and a hydrophobic membrane-associated region for proper localization to the cytoplasmic membrane or periplasmic face. The enzyme should demonstrate specificity for sugar nucleotide donors (potentially UDP-glucose, UDP-galactose, or similar) and acceptor LPS substrates, facilitating the transfer of sugar moieties to growing LPS molecules. The resulting protein should maintain optimal stability for function in the bacterial envelope environment while enabling the pathogen to evade innate immune recognition through strategic LPS modifications.

description: VFG050889(gb|WP_000783000.1) (gspM) general secretion pathway protein M [T2SS (VF1335) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Acinetobacter baumannii ACICU]
prompt: Design a protein sequence for the general secretion pathway protein M (GspM) from Acinetobacter baumannii, a critical component of the Type II Secretion System (T2SS). This organism is a significant nosocomial pathogen known for multidrug resistance and causing severe infections like pneumonia, bloodstream infections, and wound infections. GspM functions as an essential structural and regulatory component within the T2SS, which is responsible for the secretion of folded virulence factors such as proteases, lipases, and toxins from the periplasm across the outer membrane. The protein is localized to the inner membrane and periplasmic space, where it interacts with other T2SS components including the pseudopilus and the outer membrane secretin complex. Key structural features include an N-terminal transmembrane helix for membrane anchoring, a central periplasmic domain involved in protein-protein interactions, and conserved motifs that facilitate assembly and stability of the secretion machinery. The sequence should reflect these domains, ensuring proper folding for its role in mediating the ATP-dependent translocation of effector proteins, thereby contributing to the bacterium's virulence by enabling the delivery of toxins and degradative enzymes to the host environment.

description: VFG014893(gb|NP_254009) (algC) phosphomannomutase AlgC [Alginate (VF0091) - Biofilm (VFC0271)] [Pseudomonas aeruginosa PAO1]
prompt: Generate the amino acid sequence for the phosphomannomutase AlgC protein from Pseudomonas aeruginosa PAO1, a critical enzyme in the alginate biosynthesis pathway. This protein functions as a phosphomannomutase that catalyzes the interconversion of mannose-6-phosphate and mannose-1-phosphate, serving as a key regulatory node in the synthesis of alginate exopolysaccharide. AlgC is essential for biofilm formation and chronic infection establishment in this opportunistic pathogen, contributing to its persistence in cystic fibrosis lungs and other immunocompromised settings. The enzyme should contain conserved phosphomannomutase domains with the characteristic phosphoserine catalytic site for phosphate transfer, likely adopting a Rossmann-fold-like structure common to sugar isomerases. It must maintain the specific substrate binding pockets for mannose phosphates while excluding other hexose phosphates, and should exhibit the appropriate subcellular localization for integration into the cytoplasmic alginate biosynthesis machinery. The sequence should reflect the typical length and domain architecture of bacterial phosphomannomutases, with conserved catalytic residues and structural motifs necessary for its role in converting metabolic intermediates for alginate polymer assembly.

description: VFG000533(gb|NP_461792) (prgK) type III secretion system inner MS ring protein PrgK [TTSS (SPI-1 encode) (VF0116) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium str. LT2]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the PrgK protein, a critical structural component of the Type III Secretion System (T3SS) in Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium. As the inner membrane-spanning (MS) ring protein, PrgK forms the foundational scaffold that anchors the T3SS apparatus within the bacterial inner membrane, enabling the injection of virulence effector proteins directly into host cells. The protein should exhibit multiple transmembrane helices that facilitate stable integration into the inner membrane, forming a large oligomeric ring complex that serves as the mounting platform for the export apparatus and needle filament. Include conserved domains characteristic of T3SS basal body components, such as regions for protein-protein interactions with other T3SS components like PrgH (the outer membrane ring partner) and the export gate proteins. The sequence should reflect structural stability for withstanding the mechanical forces during effector translocation and should contain amphipathic regions that interact with both the lipid bilayer and aqueous compartments. Ensure the protein maintains the proper topology for coordinating with the ATPase complex and facilitating the hierarchical assembly of the entire secretion machinery, which is essential for Salmonella's invasion of intestinal epithelial cells and systemic pathogenesis.

description: VFG041258(gb|WP_010946433) (lem3) Dot/Icm type IV secretion system effector Lem3, Dephosphoryl-cholinase relieving the AnkX-mediated modification on Rab1 [Dot/Icm T4SS secreted effectors (VF0798) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Legionella pneumophila subsp. pneumophila str. Philadelphia 1]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for Lem3, a specialized Dot/Icm type IV secretion system effector protein from the bacterial pathogen Legionella pneumophila. This protein functions as a dephosphoryl-cholinase enzyme that specifically counteracts the AnkX-mediated phosphocholination modification on the host GTPase Rab1. Legionella pneumophila is a significant human pathogen responsible for Legionnaires' disease, and it employs the Dot/Icm type IV secretion system as its primary virulence mechanism to deliver effector proteins directly into host cells, enabling intracellular replication within a specialized Legionella-containing vacuole. Lem3 plays a crucial regulatory role in the temporal control of Rab1 manipulation during infection by reversing the phosphocholination modification installed by the AnkX effector, thereby fine-tuning Rab1 activity and membrane trafficking dynamics. The protein should contain conserved catalytic domains characteristic of dephosphoryl-cholinase enzymes, likely featuring a hydrolase fold with specific active site residues capable of cleaving the phosphocholine moiety from modified Rab1. As a T4SS substrate, Lem3 must include appropriate secretion signals and structural features compatible with translocation through the Dot/Icm apparatus. The protein should exhibit characteristics typical of bacterial effector proteins, including appropriate molecular weight, potential interaction surfaces for host protein recognition, and structural stability for intracellular function. The sequence should reflect the evolutionary optimization for host-pathogen interaction while maintaining functional specificity for Rab1 dephosphocholination.

description: VFG002542(gb|WP_004188690) (bspR3) N-acylhomoserine lactone-dependent regulatory protein [Quorum-sensing (VF0433) - Biofilm (VFC0271)] [Burkholderia pseudomallei K96243]
prompt: Generate the amino acid sequence for a quorum-sensing regulatory protein from Burkholderia pseudomallei, a highly virulent Gram-negative bacterium and the causative agent of melioidosis. This protein functions as an N-acylhomoserine lactone (AHL)-dependent transcriptional regulator that controls virulence gene expression in response to bacterial population density. The protein should contain characteristic domains of LuxR-type regulators, including an N-terminal autoinducer binding domain with conserved residues for AHL recognition and binding, and a C-terminal helix-turn-helix DNA-binding domain for promoter recognition and transcriptional activation. The structure should facilitate dimerization through the C-terminal domain, enabling cooperative binding to lux-box-like promoter elements. The protein must regulate biofilm formation pathways by activating expression of extracellular polysaccharide biosynthesis genes and other virulence factors in response to specific AHL signals. Include conserved motifs for ligand binding specificity, DNA interaction surfaces, and regulatory regions that mediate protein-protein interactions within the quorum-sensing network. The sequence should reflect the thermostability and structural integrity required for function in the bacterial cytoplasm while maintaining specificity for its cognate AHL signal and target promoters.

description: VFG038884(gb|WP_005314225) (lafC) LafC, flagellar export chaperone [Lateral flagella (VF0474) - Motility (VFC0204)] [Aeromonas salmonicida subsp. salmonicida A449]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for LafC, a flagellar export chaperone protein from Aeromonas salmonicida subsp. salmonicida. This protein functions as a specialized chaperone within the lateral flagellar system of this significant fish pathogen, which causes furunculosis in salmonid species. LafC plays a critical role in the type III secretion-dependent assembly of lateral flagella, which are essential for bacterial motility in viscous environments and host tissue colonization. The protein should exhibit characteristic features of flagellar export chaperones, including a compact alpha-helical bundle structure that facilitates specific binding to flagellar substrate proteins. It should contain conserved chaperone domains that prevent premature aggregation of flagellar components in the cytoplasm and mediate their targeted delivery to the flagellar type III secretion apparatus. The sequence should include motifs for ATP-independent substrate recognition and binding, typically involving hydrophobic patches and charged residues that interact with N-terminal regions of flagellar export substrates. LafC likely functions as part of a chaperone hierarchy that ensures the ordered assembly of lateral flagellar structures, with specific affinity for components of the flagellar hook-basal body complex or export apparatus. The protein should be cytoplasmic in localization and exhibit the characteristic size and physicochemical properties of class II flagellar chaperones, with appropriate surface properties for transient protein-protein interactions while maintaining solubility. The generated sequence must enable proper folding into a stable chaperone structure capable of recognizing and escorting specific flagellar substrates to the export gate while preventing their degradation or misfolding.

description: VFG049684(gb|NP_220380) (CT_858) serine protease [CPAF (VF0580) - Exoenzyme (VFC0251)] [Chlamydia trachomatis D/UW-3/CX]
prompt: Design a serine protease virulence factor from Chlamydia trachomatis, specifically the CPAF (Chlamydial Protease/Proteasome-like Activity Factor) exoenzyme. This protein is a critical virulence determinant in Chlamydia pathogenesis, functioning as a secreted protease that cleaves host cell proteins to evade immune detection and facilitate intracellular survival. The protease should exhibit chymotrypsin-like serine protease activity with a catalytic triad typically consisting of histidine, aspartate, and serine residues. It likely functions as a homodimer with a bilobed structure characteristic of CPAF, where the N-terminal domain contains regulatory elements and the C-terminal domain houses the catalytic core. The protein should contain conserved domains for substrate recognition and proteolytic activity, including substrate-binding pockets that accommodate specific host protein targets. As an exoenzyme, it requires secretion signals for translocation from the bacterial cytosol into the host cell cytoplasm, where it targets key host proteins involved in antigen presentation, apoptosis, and inflammatory signaling pathways. The structural design should ensure proper folding into the characteristic protease conformation with appropriate active site geometry for efficient substrate cleavage while maintaining stability in the host cellular environment.

description: VFG000823(gb|WP_000720639) (etgA) T3SS-associated peptidoglycan lytic enzyme  [TTSS (VF0191) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Escherichia coli O157:H7 str. EDL933]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for EtgA, a Type III Secretion System (T3SS)-associated peptidoglycan lytic enzyme from Escherichia coli O157:H7. This virulence factor is a critical component of the T3SS effector delivery system in this enteropathogenic E. coli strain, which causes severe foodborne illness and hemorrhagic colitis. EtgA functions as a specialized peptidoglycan-degrading enzyme that facilitates T3SS apparatus assembly and effector protein translocation by locally remodeling the bacterial cell wall. The enzyme likely contains conserved catalytic domains characteristic of peptidoglycan lytic transglycosylases, including a glycosyl hydrolase domain with muramidase activity that cleaves the β-1,4-glycosidic bonds between N-acetylmuramic acid and N-acetylglucosamine residues in peptidoglycan. Structural analysis suggests the protein adopts a modular architecture with a catalytic domain featuring the characteristic active site glutamate residue essential for proton donation during glycosidic bond cleavage, potentially accompanied by accessory domains that mediate interaction with the T3SS basal body components. The enzyme operates at the bacterial inner membrane-T3SS interface, where it creates localized openings in the peptidoglycan layer to accommodate the assembly of the T3SS needle complex, thereby enabling the secretion of virulence effectors into host cells. The sequence should reflect optimal catalytic efficiency for peptidoglycan degradation while maintaining structural compatibility with the T3SS machinery and membrane association properties.

description: VFG001988(gb|YP_002344798) (cysC) adenylyl-sulfate kinase [Capsule (VF0323) - Immune modulation (VFC0258)] [Campylobacter jejuni subsp. jejuni NCTC 11168]
prompt: Design a functional adenylyl-sulfate kinase enzyme from Campylobacter jejuni subsp. jejuni NCTC 11168, a major human gastrointestinal pathogen responsible for bacterial enteritis. This protein, encoded by the cysC gene, plays a critical role in the sulfate assimilation pathway by catalyzing the ATP-dependent phosphorylation of adenosine 5'-phosphosulfate (APS) to form 3'-phosphoadenosine-5'-phosphosulfate (PAPS), the universal sulfuryl group donor for cellular sulfation reactions. As a virulence factor, this enzyme contributes to capsule biosynthesis and immune modulation by enabling the sulfation of capsular polysaccharides and other surface structures that facilitate host immune evasion and colonization. The protein should contain conserved kinase domains typical of the ASK superfamily, including a nucleotide-binding P-loop motif (GXXGXGK) for ATP coordination, a catalytic loop for phosphoryl transfer, and substrate-binding pockets that specifically recognize APS while excluding other nucleotides. The structure should adopt the characteristic bilobal kinase fold with an N-terminal ATP-grasp domain and a C-terminal substrate-binding domain connected by a flexible hinge region. Key catalytic residues should be positioned to facilitate magnesium-dependent phosphoryl transfer from ATP to the 3'-OH of APS. The enzyme should exhibit optimal activity under microaerobic conditions reflective of the Campylobacter jejuni intestinal niche and maintain structural stability in the bacterial cytoplasm where it interfaces with other sulfate assimilation enzymes like sulfate adenyltransferase (CysD/CysN) and phosphoadenosine phosphosulfate reductase (CysH).

description: VFG006647(gb|WP_000963306) (flgD) flagellar basal-body rod modification protein FlgD [Flagella (VF0051) - Motility (VFC0204)] [Helicobacter pylori 26695]

The generated sequence must enable proper integration into the type III secretion-like flagellar export system and self-assembly into the characteristic tubular hook structure essential for bacterial motility and virulence.

description: VFG049915(gb|WP_001142968) (hcp2/tssD2) Type VI secretion system protein, Hcp family [T6SS (VF0579) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Shigella sonnei Ss046]

description: VFG039176(gb|NP_820623) (icmT) Type IVB secretion system protein IcmT [Dot/Icm T4SS (VF0503) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Coxiella burnetii RSA 493]
prompt: Generate the amino acid sequence for IcmT, a critical component of the Dot/Icm Type IVB secretion system from Coxiella burnetii. This intracellular bacterial pathogen causes Q fever in humans and relies on the Dot/Icm system for intracellular survival and replication within phagolysosomal compartments. IcmT functions as an essential inner membrane protein that forms part of the core transmembrane complex, facilitating the translocation of bacterial effector proteins into the host cell cytoplasm. The protein should contain multiple transmembrane domains characteristic of inner membrane localization, with both N- and C-terminal regions likely facing the bacterial cytoplasm. As part of the Type IVB secretion apparatus, IcmT interacts with other core components like IcmR, IcmS, and IcmW to form the translocation channel. The sequence should reflect conserved features of T4SS inner membrane proteins, including hydrophobic transmembrane helices, cytoplasmic domains for protein-protein interactions, and potential regions for ATPase coupling.
